definitions.definition: a strong border or structure of wood, metal, etc. that holds a picture, door, piece of glass, etc. in position

examples.text: I'm going to paint the door frame white.
She leaned against the frame of the door.

definitions.definition: the supporting structure of a piece of furniture, a building, a vehicle, etc. that gives it its shape

examples.text: The bed frame is made of pine.
the frame of an aircraft/a car/a bicycle
In the 1920s, federal office buildings were typically built with steel frames encased in concrete or granite.

definitions.definition: a structure of plastic or metal that holds the lenses in a pair of glasses
the form or structure of a person or animal’s body

examples.text: The bed was shorter than his six-foot frame.
She has quite a small frame.
a man with a lean, athletic frame

definitions.definition: the general ideas or structure that form the background to something

examples.text: In this course we hope to look at literature in the frame of its social and historical context.

definitions.definition: one of the single photographs that a film or video is made of
a single picture in a comic strip
one of the separate areas on an internet page that you can scroll through (= read by moving the text up or down)
a small wooden or metal frame covered with glass that you grow seeds or small plants in to protect them from cold weather
a single section of play in the game of snooker, etc., or in bowling

examples.text: He won the first frame easily.

definitions.definition: be taking part/not taking part in something

examples.text: We won our match, so we're still in the frame for the championship.

definitions.definition: to be wanted/not wanted by the police because you are/are not suspected of having committed a crime

examples.text: He was always in the frame for the killing.

wordOrigin: Old English framian ‘be useful’, of Germanic origin and related to from. The general sense in Middle English, ‘make ready for use’, probably led to senses (3 and 4) of the verb; it also gave rise to the specific meaning ‘prepare timber for use in building’, later ‘make the wooden parts (framework) of a building’, hence the noun sense ‘structure’ (late Middle English).
